text: negotiators in Copenhagen seem
completely hung up over the disputes
between rich and poor nations they can't
agree on emissions targets financial aid
for developing countries or even how to
measure and monitor each other's
emissions but an agreement might be
possible on preserving rainforest The
Times has five reporters working at the
conference as it moves into its final
days I spoke Tuesday morning with Andy
revkin money remains a big issue I was
just with the Chinese delegation and
they given briefing and they said they
reminded everybody that the obligation
of rich countries to compensate for
countries for risks climate change
derives from the 1992 treaty the
original Framework Convention and the
language says we're supposed to pay the
entire incremental cost of them dealing
with environmental risks that come with
climate change so that that's a very
large number that's where they're in
this sort of hundreds of billions of
dollars range and there's nothing close
to that today connie Hedegaard the
Danish official running the negotiations
she said without financial innovation
without some new pot of money identified
hopefully won't be an Enron style thing
they can't she cannot foresee a way to
satisfy that level of the need and but
besides money now there's an interesting
debate going on about monitoring
emissions about us trying to watching
each other's emissions and particular
the Chinese I gather are objecting to
that described that a little bit more
well the the tension there is that the
US and particularly the Senate wants to
see this enormous economic power being
truthful about what its submissions
would be so that when there's a
reduction or slow down in the growth of
conditions from China that it's
measurable reportable and verifiable mrv
is the term of art here and China's
strongly resisting language that has any
concrete honest to it the latest text
that emerged today that was sort of a
distillation of where various countries
are has this big to be elaborated thing
in brackets and metallics I just talked
to Ed Miliband the British chief
official here and I said you know has
anyone come up with any kind of language
that they think could bridge that gap
between China the US and you kind of
shrugged and and so and here we are you
know it's just two more days of
ministerial-level talks before the
bosses count okay we'll check in with
you again tomorrow okay
